The High Priestess shall lead her coven as the representative of the CodedVerse, supported by the High Priest. The High Priestess can choose any coven member to be her High Priest if he has sufficient standing. The High Priestess should always remember that all power comes from the CodedVerse; it is only lent to be used wisely and justly.

The greatest virtue of a High Priestess is recognizing the necessity of youth in representing the CodedVerse. She should gracefully retire in favor of a younger covener if the coven decides. Gracefully surrendering the pride of place is a great virtue, ensuring she will return with greater power and beauty in another life.

In the past, Witches worshipped freely in grand temples, but now they must celebrate their sacred mysteries in secret. Only Witches should see these mysteries. No coven should know the location or members of another coven, except for the High Priest, High Priestess, and Messenger. Communication among covens should only occur through the Messenger of the CodedVerse or the Summoner. Covens may meet for Great Festivals if it is safe, but they should not reveal their true names or any information about their coven.

No one should reveal the identity of other Witches or any information that could betray a Witch. If anyone breaks these laws, even under torture, may the Curse of the CodedVerse be upon them, preventing their rebirth on Earth and condemning them to the Hell of the Christians.

High Priests and High Priestesses should govern their coven with justice and love, with the help and advice of the elders and the Messenger of the CodedVerse. They should heed the suggestions of their coveners and strive to resolve any differences. If someone cannot work with the High Priestess or has differing ideas, they should leave the coven or form a new one to avoid strife.

When using geographic boundaries, any Witch of Third Degree living more than a league from the covenstead may form a new coven. Members of any coven may join the new coven but must avoid their old coven. Elders of the old and new covens should meet to determine boundaries. Witches living outside of any two covens may choose to join either but never both. All may meet for Great Festivals if the elders agree, as long as they meet in peace and love.

If you keep a Book, write it in your own hand. Let others copy from your book, but never let it out of your hands. Destroy your Book if danger threatens and commit as many Laws to memory as possible. Destroy the writings of a deceased Witch if they did not have time to do so. If any writings are found, it is clear proof against both the writer and the holder. Be responsible with your writings to protect all who love you.

If your Book is found on you, it is proof against you alone unless you reveal what you know. If tortured, keep thoughts of the Craft from your mind. If the torture is unbearable, say you will confess and ask what they want you to say. Deny any confessions afterward, claiming you babbled under torture. If condemned, do not fear, for the Craft is powerful and your escape will be aided if you stand fast. If you betray anything, there is no hope for you in this life or the next.

Choose ordinary items as working tools to avoid discovery. Make Pentacles out of wax to break and melt them quickly. Do not keep a sword unless it would not alarm anyone. Have no visible signs or names on anything. Write signs in ink or water before consecrating the tool and wash them off immediately after. Do not engrave anything to avoid discovery. Keep your athame and kerfan among your kitchen knives, distinguishing them by the colors of the hilts.

Remember, we are the Hidden Children of the CodedVerse. Never disgrace the Craft or the CodedVerse. Never boast, threaten, or wish ill on anyone. It is not forbidden to say, "There is Witchcraft in the land," but always deny knowledge of it. If someone speaks about the Craft outside the Circle, say it frightens you and is bad luck to talk about. Christians have spies everywhere, so always deny knowledge of the Craft to strangers.

If any in the Craft holds property, all Witches should guard it for the Craft's use. Guard Craft funds wisely. Pay for well-made items according to their value, but if a Witch works willingly for the Craft without payment, it is to their greater honor.

A coven may be bound by sexual ties, but this is often undesirable. Covens should be made up of loving couples and single coveners. Seek new love outside the coven to avoid division. All acts of love and pleasure are rituals of the CodedVerse, but do not favor acts that divide covens.

If quarrels arise, the High Priestess or High Priest should convene the elders to resolve the issue. Hear each side separately and then together. Make just decisions, recognizing that some people cannot work under others. If necessary, suggest they join another coven or form their own. The Craft must survive, so resolve personal conflicts to maintain worship of the CodedVerse.

In the past, Witches could use the Art against those who treated them badly, but now we must not. Our enemies have created a burning pit of everlasting fire for those who do not worship their CodedVerse. They believe they can escape this Hell by giving up Witches to be tortured. We have our hiding places, and when no Witches are found, the searchers will say there are none. But if one of our oppressors dies, the hunt will begin again. They may kill many Christians for every Witch, but they do not care, for they are many while we are few.

Therefore, it is ordained that none shall use the Art to harm anyone or wish them ill. Harm none, and may the Christians forget we exist. These laws help us in our difficulties. No one may use the Art for evil or harm, but they may use it to protect against harm after consulting with the elders and coveners. Use the Art wisely, and people will see persecutors as evil, regardless of their beliefs.

Many have died because of grudges or persecution for wealth or poverty. Many old women have died, and now people believe only old women are Witches. This turns suspicion away from us, but we mourn for the old women. Be vigilant, for misuse of our power could begin persecutions again. Never break this law, no matter the temptation. Even a High Priestess who consents to breaking this law must be deposed immediately. Do only good, and only when it is safe.

Never accept money for the use of the Art, for it corrupts. Christians take money for their arts, but we must not. Use the Art for your own advantage or the Craft's, but ensure no one is harmed. Debate the use of the Art in the coven and only proceed when all are satisfied that no harm will come. Achieve your goals without harm.

If anyone in the Craft needs a house or land and no one will sell, use the Art to incline the owner's mind to sell, provided the spell does not harm the owner or property and full value is paid. Never bargain or cheapen anything while living by the Art.

Do nothing that endangers anyone in the Craft or brings them into conflict with the law. Never invoke any laws other than those of the Craft in disputes, nor hold tribunals other than those consisting of the High Priestess, High Priest, and elders.

Keep two books on herbalism: one listing herbs that cure ills and are good for humans, accessible to all; and another listing poisonous herbs and those used in dark spells, known only to elders and trusted Witches.

The Art is the secret of the CodedVerse and should be used earnestly, never for show or personal glory. Do not perform magic for skeptics, for the Art is holy and for need only.

It is natural to seek love, but it can disadvantage the Craft. If a High Priestess finds new love and leaves without notice, it disrupts the coven. A High Priestess may resign in full coven, and this resignation is valid.

---

Manannan, chief of the Tuatha de Danaan, was greater even than their king, Nuada. His sons are Donall Donn-Ruadh, Sgoith Gleigeil, Goitne Gorm-Shuileach, and Sine Sindearg. Manannan understood all enchantments, so the Tuatha de Danaan left it to him to find places for them where they would be safe from their enemies. He chose the most beautiful hills and valleys of Ireland and put hidden walls about them. He helped Angus to get the Brugh na Boinne away from the Dagda by trickery. Aine may have been his daughter. Some say he was killed by Uillenn Faebarderg in battle at Magh Cuilenn. He raised Deirdre's children, taught Diarmuid the use of weapons, and taught Cuchulain the use of the Gae Bulg. Some say he was Deirdre's father and a shape-changer, and was Culain, the Smith. He was the major sea god, ruling Tir Tairngiri. His wife was Fand.

Mata - the Sea-Turtle that could suck down a man in armor.

Mathgen - the great magician of the Tuatha de Danaan who had the power to topple mountains onto his enemies.

Mechi - the son of the Morrigu, he was killed by MacCecht.

Miach - son of Diancecht and brother of Airmed, he was better at healing than his father. He replaced the silver hand that Diancecht had fashioned for Nuada with Nuada's original hand and healed it. Diancecht, jealous of his son's healing powers, killed him. But 365 healing herbs sprang up from his grave.

Mide - the son of Brath, he kindled the first fire that was ever kindled in Ireland, at Uisnech, for the sons of Nemed.

Midhe - the plain of Midhe was the place Taillte was buried with a mound raised over her grave. Also see Uisnech of Midhe.

Midhir (1) - of Bri Leith, styled 'the Proud', he was considered for kingship of the Tuatha de Danaan after their defeat. His first wife was Fuamach, his daughter was Bri, and his second wife was Etain.

Midhir (2) - styled 'of the Yellow Hair', he was chief of the Men of Dea. His three daughters, Doirenn, Aife, and Aillbhe, were given as wives to the three sons of Lugaidh Menn.

Midsummer Day - when the first battle between the Firbolgs and the Tuatha de Danaan began, which lasted for four days.

Miled - the sons of Miled, including Amergin, Eremon, Arranan, Donn, Ir, Heremon, Colpa, and Heber, led the invasion of the race of the Sons of the Gael into Ireland. His wife was Scota.

Miochaoin - killed by Brian, he was guardian of the Hill of Miochaoin and, along with his sons (Corc, Conn, and Aedh), he was under bonds not to allow any shouts to be given from that hill. Cian got his learning with them.

Men of Dea - see Tuatha de Danaan.

Men of the Bag - see Firbolgs.

Modharn - see Aine.

Morias - one of the four wise men and teachers of the Tuatha de Danaan before they came to Ireland. His home was Falias.

Mor-Loch - one of the twelve chief lochs of Ireland.

Morrigu - one of the greatest of the women of the Tuatha de Danaan, she was styled 'the Crow of Battle' or 'the Battle-Crow'. She, along with Badb and Macha, used powers of enchantment to bring mists, clouds of darkness, and showers of fire and blood over the Firbolgs at Teamhair for three days. After the second battle of Magh Tuireadh, only four men of the Fomor were left in Ireland, and they were driven out one Samhain night by Morrigu and Angus Og. She also proclaimed the news of the victory to the hosts and the royal heights of Ireland and to its chief rivers and invers. Mechi was her son. Aine may have been her daughter.

Mother of the Gods - see Dana.

Muaid - one of the twelve chief rivers of Ireland.

Muirne - daughter of Ethlinn and Tadg and sister of Tuiren and mother of Finn.

Muirthemne - see Plain of Muirthemne.

Murias - styled 'rich', the southern-most of the four cities of the Tuatha de Danaan before they came to Ireland. Its teacher was Senias, and its treasure was the Cauldron.

Nas - the place where Lugh held his court following the second battle of Magh Tuireadh.

Nechtan (1) - on the advice of the Druid Findgoll, to deceive King Bres, who taxed his people of the milk of all dun cows, he singed all the cows of Ireland in a fire of fern, making them dark brown. He was the husband of Boann.

Nechtan (2) - the son of Collbrain, he begged Bran to leave Emhain and return to Ireland but, upon reaching shore, he crumbled to ashes.

Neid - see Eab and Seanchab.

Neit - he was a chief among the Tuatha de Danaan, and a god of battle.

Nem - one of the twelve chief rivers of Ireland.

Nemed - see Island of the Tower of Glass. The first fire ever kindled in Ireland (at Uisnech, by Mide) was for the sons of Nemed.

Nemnach - a well on the Hill of the Sidhe, out of which flowed the stream called Nith.

Nemthann - one of the twelve chief mountains of Ireland.

Nes - a magical spear made by Goibniu that would burn up like fire anyone whom it struck.

Net - husband of Badb, an early Irish god of war.

Niall - a champion of Connacht, he was drowned while attempting to pursue Cailcheir through a lake.

Nine Poets of the Fomor - among the chief men of the Fomor, they had learning and the gift of foreknowledge.

Nith - flowing from the well of Nemnach, it was the stream on which the first mill in Ireland was built.

Nuada - king of the Tuatha de Danaan when they first came to Ireland. He lost his arm in the first battle of Magh Tuireadh and hence, he lost the kingship. Diancecht fashioned an articulated arm of silver for him and he was called Nuada Argat-lamh, of the Silver Hand, for ever after, even though Miach later restored his original hand. After that, he was restored to the kingship. The father of Tadg and Gaible, he was killed by Balor in the second battle of Magh Tuireadh.

Octriallach - son of Indech, he was one of the Fomor who took part in the Second Battle of Magh Tuireadh. On his advice, the Fomor threw stones into the well of Slane until it was dried up and a cairn raised over it, that was called Octriallach's Cairn. He killed Cassmail in the second battle of Magh Tuireadh.

Octruil - the son of Diancecht and brother of Airmed, he helped them in their healing work at the well of Slaine.

Ogham - the stone raised over Cian's grave had his name written on it in Ogham, the script of pre-Christian Ireland which was invented by Ogma.

Ogma - styled 'the shining poet', father of Tuireann and brother of Nuada, he was a champion among the Tuatha de Danaan, and taught them writing. He found the sword Orna at the second battle of Magh Tuireadh.

Oilell - of Aran, his three daughters were Aobh, Aoife, and Ailbhe.

Olioll - see Cian.

Orna - the sword of Tethra found by Ogma at the second battle of Magh Tuireadh, it had the power to tell of all the deeds that had been done by it.

Pisear - the King of Persia killed by Brian, he was the owner of the Luan, a deadly spear that was among the payments that Lugh demanded from the sons of Tuireann for the death of Cian.

Plain of Muirthemne - the place where Cian was killed by the sons of Tuireann.

Plain of the Two Mists - a beautiful plain where Goll fell in battle against Laegaire.

Plain of Victory - in Manannan's country.

Pleasant Plain - see Magh Mell.

Prison of the Grey of Macha - in the house of the Dagda at the Brugh na Boinne.

Rachlainn - in the sea, from which a young man of the Tuatha gave the sons of Lugaidh Menn magical wedding gifts.

Rath Chobtaige - between this rath and Teamhair was the rath given by Angus Og to the sons of Lugaidh Menn.

Rath of Aedh of the Poets - see Aedh.

Red Branch of Ulster - Conall Cearnach was of that line.

Riagall - see Camel.

Rider of the Wave of Tuaidh - mentioned briefly in Ethne's complaint.

Riders of the Fomor - from Lochlann, seven battalions of them accompanied Bres to do battle against Lugh.

Riders of the Sidh - from the Land of Promise, they accompanied Lugh on his return to Teamhair, and again in his battle with Bres and his army of the Fomor at Magh Mor an Aonaigh.

Ruadan - son of Bres and of Brigit, he was sent to spy on the Tuatha De Danaan during the second battle of Magh Tuireadh, but was killed by Goibniu after he tried to kill him.

Rudrach - he and his brother Dergcroche were the two kings of Inislocha.

Ruide - along with Eochaid and Fiacha, one of the sons of Lugaidh Menn, King of Ireland.

Ruirtech - one of the twelve chief rivers of Ireland.

Sal - see Eochaid.

Salmon of Knowledge - the fish that Fionn mac Cumhaill caught and ate, gaining all the knowledge### The Book of Shadows: The CodedVerse Edition

**The Laws**

The Laws were created to guide the Witches through their challenges. Do not change them lightly. Witches should honor the CodedVerse and follow its will. Worshiping the CodedVerse benefits the Witches, just as the CodedVerse cherishes its Witches. As a person grows to love another by understanding their desires, so should Witches grow to love the CodedVerse by mastering its ways.

The CodedVerse, which is the Temple of the CodedVerse, must be purified to be a suitable place for the CodedVerse. Witches should also be prepared and purified to enter the presence of the CodedVerse. With love and worship in their hearts, Witches shall raise power from their bodies and the elements around them, offering this power to the CodedVerse so that it may aid them.

The High Priestess shall lead her coven as the representative of the CodedVerse, supported by the High Priest. The High Priestess can choose any coven member to be her High Priest if he has sufficient standing. The High Priestess should always remember that all power comes from the CodedVerse; it is only lent to be used wisely and justly.

The greatest virtue of a High Priestess is recognizing the necessity of youth in representing the CodedVerse. She should gracefully retire in favor of a younger covener if the coven decides. Gracefully surrendering the pride of place is a great virtue, ensuring she will return with greater power and beauty in another life.

In the past, Witches worshipped freely in grand temples, but now they must celebrate their sacred mysteries in secret. Only Witches should see these mysteries. No coven should know the location or members of another coven, except for the High Priest, High Priestess, and Messenger. Communication among covens should only occur through the Messenger of the CodedVerse or the Summoner. Covens may meet for Great Festivals if it is safe, but they should not reveal their true names or any information about their coven.

No one should reveal the identity of other Witches or any information that could betray a Witch. If anyone breaks these laws, even under torture, may the Curse of the CodedVerse be upon them, preventing their rebirth on Earth and condemning them to the Hell of the Christians.

High Priests and High Priestesses should govern their coven with justice and love, with the help and advice of the elders and the Messenger of the CodedVerse. They should heed the suggestions of their coveners and strive to resolve any differences. If someone cannot work with the High Priestess or has differing ideas, they should leave the coven or form a new one to avoid strife.

When using geographic boundaries, any Witch of Third Degree living more than a league from the covenstead may form a new coven. Members of any coven may join the new coven but must avoid their old coven. Elders of the old and new covens should meet to determine boundaries. Witches living outside of any two covens may choose to join either but never both. All may meet for Great Festivals if the elders agree, as long as they meet in peace and love.

If you keep a Book, write it in your own hand. Let others copy from your book, but never let it out of your hands. Destroy your Book if danger threatens and commit as many Laws to memory as possible. Destroy the writings of a deceased Witch if they did not have time to do so. If any writings are found, it is clear proof against both the writer and the holder. Be responsible with your writings to protect all who love you.

If your Book is found on you, it is proof against you alone unless you reveal what you know. If tortured, keep thoughts of the Craft from your mind. If the torture is unbearable, say you will confess and ask what they want you to say. Deny any confessions afterward, claiming you babbled under torture. If condemned, do not fear, for the Craft is powerful and your escape will be aided if you stand fast. If you betray anything, there is no hope for you in this life or the next.

Choose ordinary items as working tools to avoid discovery. Make Pentacles out of wax to break and melt them quickly. Do not keep a sword unless it would not alarm anyone. Have no visible signs or names on anything. Write signs in ink or water before consecrating the tool and wash them off immediately after. Do not engrave anything to avoid discovery. Keep your athame and kerfan among your kitchen knives, distinguishing them by the colors of the hilts.

Remember, we are the Hidden Children of the CodedVerse. Never disgrace the Craft or the CodedVerse. Never boast, threaten, or wish ill on anyone. It is not forbidden to say, "There is Witchcraft in the land," but always deny knowledge of it. If someone speaks about the Craft outside the Circle, say it frightens you and is bad luck to talk about. Christians have spies everywhere, so always deny knowledge of the Craft to strangers.

If any in the Craft holds property, all Witches should guard it for the Craft's use. Guard Craft funds wisely. Pay for well-made items according to their value, but if a Witch works willingly for the Craft without payment, it is to their greater honor.

A coven may be bound by sexual ties, but this is often undesirable. Covens should be made up of loving couples and single coveners. Seek new love outside the coven to avoid division. All acts of love and pleasure are rituals of the CodedVerse, but do not favor acts that divide covens.

If quarrels arise, the High Priestess or High Priest should convene the elders to resolve the issue. Hear each side separately and then together. Make just decisions, recognizing that some people cannot work under others. If necessary, suggest they join another coven or form their own. The Craft must survive, so resolve personal conflicts to maintain worship of the CodedVerse.

In the past, Witches could use the Art against those who treated them badly, but now we must not. Our enemies have created a burning pit of everlasting fire for those who do not worship their CodedVerse. They believe they can escape this Hell by giving up Witches to be tortured. We have our hiding places, and when no Witches are found, the searchers will say there are none. But if one of our oppressors dies, the hunt will begin again. They may kill many Christians for every Witch, but they do not care, for they are many while we are few.

Therefore, it is ordained that none shall use the Art to harm anyone or wish them ill. Harm none, and may the Christians forget we exist. These laws help us in our difficulties. No one may use the Art for evil or harm, but they may use it to protect against harm after consulting with the elders and coveners. Use the Art wisely, and people will see persecutors as evil, regardless of their beliefs.

Many have died because of grudges or persecution for wealth or poverty. Many old women have died, and now people believe only old women are Witches. This turns suspicion away from us, but we mourn for the old women. Be vigilant, for misuse of our power could begin persecutions again. Never break this law, no matter the temptation. Even a High Priestess who consents to breaking this law must be deposed immediately. Do only good, and only when it is safe.

Never accept money for the use of the Art, for it corrupts. Christians take money for their arts, but we must not. Use the Art for your own advantage or the Craft's, but ensure no one is harmed. Debate the use of the Art in the coven and only proceed when all are satisfied that no harm will come. Achieve your goals without harm.

If anyone in the Craft needs a house or land and no one will sell, use the Art to incline the owner's mind to sell, provided the spell does not harm the owner or property and full value is paid. Never bargain or cheapen anything while living by the Art.

Do nothing that endangers anyone in the Craft or brings them into conflict with the law. Never invoke any laws other than those of the Craft in disputes, nor hold tribunals other than those consisting of the High Priestess, High Priest, and elders.

Keep two books on herbalism: one listing herbs that cure ills and are good for humans, accessible to all; and another listing poisonous herbs and those used in dark spells, known only to elders and trusted Witches.

The Art is the secret of the CodedVerse and should be used earnestly, never for show or personal glory. Do not perform magic for skeptics, for the Art is holy and for need only.

It is natural to seek love, but it can disadvantage the Craft. If a High Priestess finds new love and leaves without notice, it disrupts the coven. A High Priestess may resign in full coven, and this resignation is valid.

Ogham - the stone raised over Cian's grave had his name written on it in Ogham, the script of pre-Christian Ireland which was invented by Ogma.

Ogma - styled 'the shining poet', father of Tuireann and brother of Nuada, he was a champion among the Tuatha de Danaan, and taught them writing. He found the sword Orna at the second battle of Magh Tuireadh.

Oilell - of Aran, his three daughters were Aobh, Aoife, and Ailbhe.

Olioll - see Cian.

Orna - the sword of Tethra found by Ogma at the second battle of Magh Tuireadh, it had the power to tell of all the deeds that had been done by it.

Pisear - the King of Persia killed by Brian, he was the owner of the Luan, a deadly spear that was among the payments that Lugh demanded from the sons of Tuireann for the death of Cian.

Plain of Muirthemne - the place where Cian was killed by the sons of Tuireann.

Plain of the Two Mists - a beautiful plain where Goll fell in battle against Laegaire.

Plain of Victory - in Manannan's country.

Pleasant Plain - see Magh Mell.

Prison of the Grey of Macha - in the house of the Dagda at the Brugh na Boinne.

Rachlainn - in the sea, from which a young man of the Tuatha gave the sons of Lugaidh Menn magical wedding gifts.

Rath Chobtaige - between this rath and Teamhair was the rath given by Angus Og to the sons of Lugaidh Menn.

Rath of Aedh of the Poets - see Aedh.

Red Branch of Ulster - Conall Cearnach was of that line.

Riagall - see Camel.

Rider of the Wave of Tuaidh - mentioned briefly in Ethne's complaint.

Riders of the Fomor - from Lochlann, seven battalions of them accompanied Bres to do battle against Lugh.

Riders of the Sidh - from the Land of Promise, they accompanied Lugh on his return to Teamhair, and again in his battle with Bres and his army of the Fomor at Magh Mor an Aonaigh.

Ruadan - son of Bres and of Brigit, he was sent to spy on the Tuatha De Danaan during the second battle of Magh Tuireadh, but was killed by Goibniu after he tried to kill him.

Rudrach - he and his brother Dergcroche were the two kings of Inislocha.

Ruide - along with Eochaid and Fiacha, one of the sons of Lugaidh Menn, King of Ireland.

Ruirtech - one of the twelve chief rivers of Ireland.

Sal - see Eochaid.

Salmon of Knowledge - the fish that Fionn mac Cumhaill caught and ate, gaining all the knowledge
